We are currently in discussion with the customer _*Medtronics*_, who is looking to integrate *AEM with Workday*.
We had recommended using *custom authentication* for this purpose. After implementing the custom authentication and providing the required details, the customer was successfully able to connect to Workday.
Recently, we received a query via email from the customer regarding support needed during *form authoring*.

*Use Case:*
They would like to implement an *autocomplete textbox* that fetches data from the *Form Data Model (FDM)* by invoking a service using the *Rule Editor*, triggered on *keypress*.
Currently, the customer is using *foundation components* for form creation. We have suggested switching to *core components* for greater flexibility.
As also recommended by <@W4R5M9P4H> and <@U02DW7JLT62>, this use case can be achieved using a *custom component*.

With a custom component, we can *trigger a change event on keypress*, and then create a rule on that change event to *invoke the service*.
A similar implementation has already been done for *HDFC*.

Adding <@W4XTCQ07J> to help us unblock the customer for form authoring.

• *Introduction:* Arun, Ben McKnight, Vijay Kumar, Andy, and Sarah discussed the discovery work on the platform team, focusing on the requirements for Marketo form components shared across all brands. The meeting aimed to review the findings and confirm the requirements with Sarah's team. 
• *Marketo Form Requirements:* Ben McKnight presented the high-level requirements for the Marketo form component, which includes ease of use, custom scripts for analytics, collecting location data, configurable form names, and campaign tracking. The document covers all EBG and Marine forms. 
• *Form Customisation and API Integration:* Vijay Kumar and Andy discussed the static values in the forms and the potential need for API integration for dynamic data. They also talked about the possibility of introducing custom components for Google Places autocomplete and other dynamic behaviours. 
• *Form Creation Process:* Ben McKnight explained the current process for form creation, which involves the Marketo team building the form and the author adding it to the page. Andy mentioned the recent changes towards more component-based styling and the need for documentation on dynamic setups for country and language. 
• *Project Timeline and Collaboration:* Sarah and Andy discussed the project timeline, aiming for an August go-live date for the European group. Arun suggested setting up a Teams channel for collaboration and weekly meetings to track progress and address any blockers. 
• *Marketo Integration and Access:* Arun and Andy discussed the need for access to Marketo and AEM instances for the team. They also talked about the possibility of using hidden fields to segment data by region and the need for further discussions on Edge delivery services.

Existing AEM Forms JEE customer inherited from LiveCycle days, on-prem, ~178K product + 80K paid support renewal upcoming. Field team targeting as-is renewal for now.

Customer is exploring to implement a new use-case (details below) in JEE by deploying a new server and looking for our guidance for the same.

My understanding is they should do following to reduce complexity:
1. End user to open XFA PDF, enter data and submit to JEE workflow exposed over REST. Add a field in form data to send email confirmation.
2. In workflow, extract data using process form submission, add a unique identifier, submit XML data to Oracle DB, store PDF with data into Documentum and send confirmation email for successful processing else log error.
In my mind, they don't need to submit to email endpoint, then monitor via IBM MQ and send to AEM server to achieve their use-case.

Requesting JEE experts to confirm. Need to revert to customer by Tue 07/29.

Meeting recording: <https://teams.microsoft.com/l/meetingrecap?driveId=b%21CtcLxeV1REG58cDoQgQrbdtap5Dhs9pBr6uC3_2FeyLqlgY_n1S7TpknV52fuUYs&driveItemId=01GJG53GJUW77K6WY6KBCJR7ARG5XE5FHL&sitePath=https%3A%2F%2Fadobe-my.sharepoint.com%2F%3Av%3A%2Fp%2Fmasmal%2FETS3_q9bHlBEmPwRN25OlOsB3mDAwTgFZOi4tWbRckV_mg&fileUrl=https%3A%2F%2Fadobe-my.sharepoint.com%2F%3Av%3A%2Fp%2Fmasmal%2FETS3_q9bHlBEmPwRN25OlOsB3mDAwTgFZOi4tWbRckV_mg&iCalUid=040000008200E00074C5B7101A82E00800000000FADAD7D66CF5DB01000000000000000010000000D312109A76880D4590439E6BCBA450B2&threadId=19%3Ameeting_ZjYzMjVjZjAtNjg2Yi00MWFlLWFlYzAtYTg3YmIwNTJiMzc1%40thread.v2&organizerId=7c1a8d2d-7d21-481e-94ff-ba71d8a1a6d2&tenantId=fa7b1b5a-7b34-4387-94ae-d2c178decee1&callId=2ce5c01b-c47d-40fe-968c-26411bb9fbc9&threadType=Meeting&meetingType=Scheduled&subType=RecapSharingLink_RecapChiclet|Recap: SAPS Incident Shooting Use Case Discusison 23 July | Meeting | Microsoft Teams>

Use Case: End-to-End Submission Workflow in Adobe Workbench 6.5
1. Overview
This document outlines a workflow built in Adobe Workbench 6.5, connected to AEM Forms JEE server, for managing PDF submissions, XML processing, ECM storage, and IBM MQ integration. The workflow leverages:
- Dynamic XFA PDF templates
- XSD-based XML validation
- Documentum for ECM
- IBM MQ for inter-system communication
- Email (SMTP/POP3/IMAP) for notifications
2. Actors & Systems
- Submitter: User sending a form via email.
- AEM Forms Server (Workbench 6.5): Core process orchestration.
- IBM MQ: Transmits base64-encoded PDFs.
- Documentum ECM: Stores final PDFs.
- Email Server: Receives input and sends acknowledgments.
3. Input Artifacts
- XFA PDF (dynamic template)
- XML schema (XSD)
- Email with attached PDF (user submission)
- IBM MQ message (base64-encoded PDF)
- Submitter’s email address
4. Workflow Steps
Step 1: New Application and Process Initialization
A new AEM Forms application is created in Adobe Workbench. Process template includes: Email configurations, Java services for MQ and ECM, Signature processing (optional).
Step 2: Receive Email & Extract PDF Attachment
Use email server configuration to receive PDFs extracted from emails.
Step 3: IBM Picks Up the PDF
IBM MQ reads from the Email server, pick up the PDF XML data.
Step 4: Extract XML from PDF & Convert to Base64
Extract XML from PDF, (validate against XSD), and generates (UID) send base64-encoded string via MQ to Adobe server.
Step 5: Adobe Receives Base64 via MQ (Java Service)
Receives MQ message base64 with embedded UID.
Step 6: Convert Base64 to PDF Document
Decode base64 and create a Document variable (To store to Documentum).
Step 7: Export Form Data (XML)
Extract form data as XML and validate against XSD.
Step 8: Embed Digital Signature into XML (Optional/TBC)
Embed digital signature using XMLDSIG (if required).
Step 9: Generate GUID and Inject into XML
Generate UUID and inject into XML.
Step 10: Inject Submitter Email Address
Inject user’s email into XML for tracking and Acknowledgment email.
Step 11: Store PDF in Documentum (ECM)
Store PDF via SendDocToDocumentum component and return ECM UID.
Step 12: Send Acknowledgment or Failure Email
Notify user of success or failure with UID/logs.
Step 13: Log the Submission
Log metadata in DB, file, or XML store.
Step 14: End Process
Cleanup and terminate process.

5. Technical Notes
Email server Configuration
IBM Monitor directory for `.pdf` files.
IBM MQ Integration
Custom Java component using JMS API. Handles queue read/write with secure credentials.
Documentum Integration
Uses AEM Forms Documentum connector or Web Service.
Email Configuration
SMTP for outgoing, IMAP/POP3 for incoming (optional).
XML Validation
Import XSD into Workbench. Use Validate XML service activity.

6. Attachments & Dependencies
Resource                                                                   Type                                         Required
form-template.xdp                                             XFA PDF                                      :white_check_mark:
schema-definition.xsd                                      XSD Schema                         :white_check_mark:
mq-config.properties                                        Config                                       :white_check_mark:
SendDocToDocumentum                               AEM Add-on                         :white_check_mark:
email-template.html                                          HTML                                   Optional
7. Success Criteria
- Email received and processed.
- PDF successfully extracted and converted.
- XML validated and signed (if required).
- Data stored in Documentum with confirmation.
- User receives email acknowledgment.

Meeting Summary: Key Issues Raised by NFCU and Our Responses

Below is a summary of the key concerns raised by NFCU during the meeting, along with our corresponding responses:
*1. FDM JSON Format Issue*
    ◦ *Issue*: FDM is not generating sample data due to discrepancies in the JSON format.
    ◦ *Response*: Vijay suggested initiating the process with a simplified Swagger JSON to manually construct the required structure.
*2. Template Selection & Page Preset*
    ◦ *Issue*: Unclear behavior observed in template and page preset configurations.
    ◦ *Response*: Vijay confirmed that the relevant changes are currently under PR review. These updates will enable paper size selection after template creation.
*3. Font Rendering in PDF Preview*
    ◦ *Issue*: Fonts are not rendering as expected and are defaulting to fallback fonts.
    ◦ *Response*: Vijay clarified that fonts must be available on the server. If a font is missing, the system defaults to a fallback font.
*4. Custom Font Upload*
    ◦ *Issue*: Requirement to upload custom fonts to the server.
    ◦ *Response*: Prateek confirmed that this is feasible via the AEM workflow and offered to share the relevant Adobe documentation.
*5. Content Overflow Limitation*
    ◦ *Issue*: Text content is being truncated within text boxes.
    ◦ *Response*: Vijay explained that only element-level overflow is currently supported; content overflow functionality is not yet implemented.
*6. Template vs. IC Editor Restrictions*
    ◦ *Issue*: The IC Editor permits layout and font changes that are restricted by templates.
    ◦ *Response*: Vijay acknowledged the inconsistency and confirmed that efforts are underway to align IC Editor behavior with template constraints.
*7. Pagination & Master Page Settings*
    ◦ *Issue*: Need to validate pagination across multiple pages.
    ◦ *Response*: Vijay and the NFCU team jointly tested and confirmed that pagination is functioning correctly. These settings are applied through the master page configuration.
*8. Subform & Content Area Deletion*
    ◦ *Issue*: Inability to delete subforms and content areas.
    ◦ *Response*: Vijay acknowledged the issue and committed to investigating further.
*9. Documentation for IC Editor*
    ◦ *Issue*: Absence of official documentation for the IC Editor.
    ◦ *Response*: Vijay mentioned that Adobe is actively working on the documentation, though no ETA.

Meeting notes:
• *Introduction to AI Innovations in AM Forms:* Jochen and Anurag introduced the session on AI innovations in AM forms, highlighting the involvement of the product management team and the focus on generative AI, multimodal capabilities, and forms optimisation.
    ◦ *Session Introduction:* Jochen initiated the session by mentioning the recording disclaimer and encouraging participants to turn on their cameras. He introduced the purpose of the meeting, which was to delve deeper into AI innovations in AM forms, a conversation that started two weeks ago. He highlighted the presence of the product management team and handed over to Anurag to lead the session.

He outlined the session's agenda, which included demos on generative AI for authoring interfaces, multimodal capabilities, and forms optimisation.
• *Generative AI for Authoring Interfaces:* Anurag demonstrated how generative AI can be used to create forms quickly using screenshots, photos, or simple scribbles, showcasing the ability to detect fields and apply brand templates.
    ◦ *Form Creation:* Anurag demonstrated the use of generative AI to create forms from various inputs such as screenshots, photos, or scribbles. He showed how a business user could quickly brainstorm and create a form by uploading a photo or screenshot to the generative AI assistant, which then detects fields and generates a form.
    ◦ *Brand Templates:* Anurag explained that the generative AI assistant allows users to apply brand-specific templates and styles to the generated forms, ensuring consistency with the brand's design guidelines.
    ◦ *Authoring Assistant:* Anurag showcased another demo where the authoring assistant suggests fields for a form based on a simple command, such as "create a form with personal information panel." The assistant automatically adds the suggested fields to the form, which can then be customized further.
• *Multimodal Form Filling:* Anurag explained the multimodal capabilities introduced for form filling, including chat-based interactions and document uploads, which enhance the user experience and improve conversion rates.
    ◦ *Chat-Based Interaction:* Anurag demonstrated how users can interact with forms through a chat-based interface embedded within the form. This chat experience allows users to fill out forms conversationally, making the process more intuitive and user-friendly.
    ◦ *Document Uploads:* Anurag showed how users can upload identification documents, and the system extracts relevant information to prefill the form fields. This reduces the manual effort required to fill out forms and improves accuracy.
    ◦ *Field Types:* Anurag highlighted that the chat-based interface supports various field types, including dropdowns, multiple select options, and yes/no questions, making it versatile for different form requirements.
• *Click to Fill Modality:* Anurag showcased the Click to Fill modality, which allows users to indicate damage on a car image or other visual elements, making form filling more intuitive and reducing errors.
    ◦ *Damage Indication:* Anurag demonstrated the Click to Fill modality using a car insurance claim form. Users can click on parts of a car image to indicate where the damage occurred and select the damage intensity, which automatically fills the corresponding fields in the form.
    ◦ *Use Cases:* Anurag mentioned that this modality is useful in various industries, such as dental and aerospace, where users need to indicate specific areas of concern visually. This approach reduces errors and makes the form-filling process more intuitive.
• *Forms Optimisation:* Anurag discussed the AM sites optimiser product, which identifies opportunities to improve form interfaces, such as reducing the number of fields or improving discoverability, to enhance conversion rates.
    ◦ *Optimisation Opportunities:* Anurag explained that the AM sites optimiser product analyses forms to identify areas for improvement, such as reducing the number of fields or changing the layout to a progressive disclosure format. These optimisations aim to enhance user experience and increase conversion rates.
    ◦ *Insight and Suggestions:* Anurag highlighted that the optimiser provides insights and suggestions based on the analysis, such as indicating that a form looks complicated and recommending a more user-friendly layout. The optimiser can automatically create variations of the form for testing and comparison.
• *Integration with Customer's LLM:* Matthias and Vijay discussed the flexibility of integrating the customer's own LLM, such as Gemini DBLLM, with AM forms, considering the data security and governance requirements.
    ◦ *LLM Integration:* Matthias raised concerns about data security and governance when using LLMs. Vijay explained that Adobe has a standard agreement with Microsoft for using Azure Open AI models, ensuring that customer data is not used for training. He also mentioned the possibility of integrating the customer's own LLM, such as Gemini DBLLM, with AM forms.
    ◦ *Data Security:* Vijay assured that the integration with Azure Open AI models ensures data security and that customer data is not used for training the models. He also mentioned that customers could use their own LLMs to maintain control over their data.
• *Data Extraction from Scanned Forms:* Matthias and Vijay explored the possibility of extracting data from scanned forms and unstructured documents, highlighting the use of adaptive forms and the importance of document quality.
    ◦ *Data Extraction:* Matthias inquired about extracting data from scanned forms and unstructured documents. Vijay explained that the system could extract data from various document types, including handwritten forms, and convert it into a structured format for further processing.
    ◦ *Document Quality:* Vijay emphasized the importance of document quality for accurate data extraction. He mentioned that the system performs well with clear and well-defined documents but may face challenges with poor-quality scans or complex handwriting.
• *Technical Integration and Data Security:* Birgit and Vijay discussed the technical aspects of integrating AM forms with the customer's systems, including data encryption, secure storage, and the use of preprocessor and postprocessor hooks.
    ◦ *Data Encryption:* Birgit inquired about data encryption during integration. Vijay explained that AM forms support data encryption using preprocessor and postprocessor hooks, allowing customers to implement their encryption methods for secure data transfer.
    ◦ *Secure Storage:* Vijay mentioned that AM forms do not store user-entered data. Instead, the data is processed in memory and passed directly to the customer's storage endpoint, ensuring data security and compliance with regulations.
• *Sandbox Environment for POC:* Nitesh and Anurag discussed the availability of a sandbox environment for proof of concept (POC) purposes, with the possibility of enabling generative AI capabilities after accepting a beta agreement.
• *Next Steps and Follow-up:* Jochen summarised the next steps, including sending out the recording, meeting notes, and coordinating another meeting to discuss migration topics, while ensuring the sandbox environment is ready for use.

*Meeting notes*
• *Intent-Based Experience Creation with Gen AI:* Anurag, Sudhanshu, and the team discussed Adobe's approach to customer experience management using intent-based experiences powered by Gen AI, focusing on generating, activating, and optimizing user experiences for end users and customers.
    ◦ *Three Pillars Overview:* Anurag outlined the three key pillars for creating performant experiences: generation (using tools like Edge Delivery Services and Universal Editor), activation (with multimodal forms), and optimization (identifying and fixing opportunities for improvement).
    ◦ *Unified Authoring:* The team explained the concept of unified authoring, where both pages and forms can be created within a single editor, allowing authors to drag and drop adaptive form components in either the Universal Editor or the site editor using core components.
    ◦ *AI-Assisted Form Creation:* Anurag demonstrated the Forms Experience Builder, an AI assistant that enables authors to create forms by expressing intent in natural language, with Gen AI suggesting appropriate fields, layouts, and even basic rules, which can then be applied directly to the form.
    ◦ *Limitations and Parity:* It was clarified that the AI assistant is currently available in the AEM Forms editor and not in the core component side of the sites page builder, but unified authoring experiences are maintained across editors for consistency.
• *AI-Driven Form Generation from Visual Inputs:* Anurag presented capabilities for generating forms from screenshots, Figma exports, legacy forms, hand-drawn sketches, and PDF forms, allowing users to upload visual references and have the system extract and build forms automatically.
    ◦ *Screenshot and Sketch Extraction:* The team showcased how users can upload screenshots or hand-drawn sketches, and the system will analyze the image to extract fields, identify optional fields, and add relevant components such as attachments and submit buttons.
    ◦ *PDF Form Conversion:* Anurag explained the process of uploading PDF forms into the Experience Builder, which then converts them into adaptive forms, applying brand-approved templates and style guides as part of the conversion.
• *Authoring Versus Developer Roles and Customization:* Lauren, Jitendra, and others discussed the division of responsibilities between authors and developers, focusing on what can be automated by AI and what still requires manual intervention, especially for integrations, styling, and error handling.
    ◦ *Author-Focused Features:* Anurag clarified that the AI assistant is primarily intended for authors, enabling them to quickly create forms, while developers are responsible for configuring data sources, integrations, and custom components.
    ◦ *Integration and Error Handling:* Lauren and Jitendra raised questions about integrating forms with systems like Marketo or Salesforce and handling errors; Vijay Kumar and Sudhanshu explained that while some integrations can be configured via connectors and templates, advanced error handling and customizations still require developer involvement.
    ◦ *Styling and Customization Roadmap:* Jitendra asked about AI-driven styling, and Anurag confirmed that updating styles via AI is on the roadmap, with current support for leveraging Figma styles and plans to further automate style updates.
• *Security, Captcha, and Analytics Integration:* Jitendra, Sudhanshu, and Vijay Kumar discussed security features such as Captcha integration, how these are configured, and the analytics capabilities available for forms, including out-of-the-box integration with Adobe Analytics.
    ◦ *Captcha Support:* Sudhanshu and Vijay Kumar explained that various Captcha types (Google Captcha, Edge Capture, Turnstile, enterprise Captcha) are supported, and can be added manually or via templates, with cloud configuration for reuse across forms.
    ◦ *Analytics Integration:* Anurag and Sudhanshu described the out-of-the-box integration with Adobe Analytics for core component-based forms, and the availability of operational telemetry data for monitoring form performance without requiring AI.
• *Multimodal Forms and Advanced User Interactions:* Anurag and Sudhanshu introduced multimodal forms, which allow end users to interact with forms through conversational interfaces, document scanning, and click-to-fill features, supporting diverse use cases such as healthcare and insurance.
    ◦ *Conversational Interface:* The team demonstrated how users can fill forms via a conversational interface embedded within the form, with the ability to switch between conversation and traditional views, and preview or submit forms from either interface.
    ◦ *Document Scanning and Prefill:* Anurag described how users can upload identification documents, which are scanned to prefill relevant form fields, reducing manual entry and cognitive load.
    ◦ *Click-to-Fill and SVG Mapping:* Sudhanshu explained the use of SVGs and custom components to enable users to click on images (e.g., a car or body part) to indicate areas of interest, with the system mapping these selections to form fields.
• *Form Optimization and Sites Optimizer:* Anurag and Sudhanshu detailed the Sites Optimizer tool, which identifies and suggests optimizations for forms and site content, including conversion rates, accessibility, and other performance metrics, with plans for auto-optimization features.
    ◦ *Opportunity Detection:* The Sites Optimizer identifies opportunities such as low form views, poor navigation, low conversion rates, and accessibility issues, providing prescriptive suggestions and, in some cases, alternative variations for improvement.
    ◦ *Operational Telemetry and AI Models:* Sudhanshu explained that the optimizer uses operational telemetry data and AI models to analyze user interactions and generate actionable insights, with current support for auto-detection and suggestions, and ongoing work towards auto-fixing certain issues.
    ◦ *Migration and Compatibility:* The optimizer supports both adaptive forms and third-party forms for opportunity detection, but auto-optimization features are currently limited to adaptive forms.
• *Migration from Foundation to Core Components:* Ashajyoti, Pradeep, and Sudhanshu discussed the challenges and process of migrating forms from foundation-based components to core components, including code compatibility, rule migration, and the benefits of modernization.
    ◦ *Migration Process and Challenges:* The team discussed that while the structure of forms can be migrated, rule sets currently need to be redefined manually, which is a significant effort for teams with many forms and complex rules.
    ◦ *Modernization Benefits:* Sudhanshu and Vijay Kumar highlighted that core components offer better performance, easier styling, and support for modern JavaScript (ES6+), as well as advanced features like headless and multi-channel support.
    ◦ *Incremental Migration Strategy:* It was recommended to keep existing forms on foundation components if immediate migration is not feasible, and to use core components for new forms to gradually modernize the codebase.
• *Custom Component Development and Support:* Pradeep, Ashajyoti, and the team discussed the development of custom components, challenges with extending existing components, and the support available for troubleshooting and documentation.
    ◦ *Custom Component Creation:* Pradeep described efforts to create a custom auto-suggestion field by extending the text field component, with the team requesting design references or screenshots to assist with support.
    ◦ *Troubleshooting and Documentation:* Ashajyoti raised issues with copying structures and JavaScript compatibility after migration, and Sudhanshu recommended sharing code for review and consulting documentation, especially when moving to core components.
• *Next Steps and Follow-Up Actions:* Anurag outlined the next steps, including enabling features on dev servers, scheduling follow-up sessions, collecting collateral and sample forms, and enrolling interested teams in the VIP program for early access and feedback.
    ◦ *Feature Enablement:* The team agreed to enable Forms Experience Builder and related features on dev servers upon receiving the necessary program and org IDs from the customer team.
    ◦ *Follow-Up Sessions:* Anurag committed to scheduling follow-up meetings to address outstanding questions, review migration strategies, and provide hands-on support for enabling and using new features.
